awd_titl_txt: Geometric Methods in Modular Representation Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
A matrix group is a set of invertible square matrices that contains all products and inverses of its members. Typical examples include O(3,R), the group of orthogonal 3x3 matrices with real entries, and SU(2), the group of 2x2 unitary complex matrices.  Broadly speaking, the subject of representation theory deals with how such groups can act on a (complex) vector space via linear transformations.  One can then ask what happens if we replace the complex numbers by a finite field (or the algebraic closure of a finite field). Modular representation theory is concerned with matrix groups with entries in such a field, acting on vector spaces over the same field. The proposed research will make advances in modular representation theory by geometric methods. Many of the anticipated results are analogous to known facts in complex representation theory, but new tools and techniques must be developed in the modular case.   
 
The past few years have seen the emergence of powerful new tools for applying geometric methods to the representation theory of algebraic groups in positive characteristic, including parity sheaves and the mixed modular derived category. This project will build on these developments with projects on three different topics: (i) monodromy operators in positive characteristic; (ii) generalized Springer theory for coherent sheaves; and (iii) Kazhdan-Lusztig cells, tensor ideals, and tilting modules. Topic (i) is essentially geometric in nature, while topics (ii) and (iii) are expected to have concrete consequences for representation theory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported research in representation theory, which is the study of symmetries of linear systems.  The term "linear" means (in part) that these symmetries should be invariant under multiplication by scalars.  Traditionally, "scalars" usually refers to real numbers of complex numbers, but scalars can come from other settings, such as arithmetic modulo p, where p is a prime number.  Representation theory with scalars modulo p -- also called "modular representation theory" -- is a very active field of current research that has seen tremendous advances in the past decade.

This project is focused more specifically on the use of tools from geometry and topology to answer questions in (modular) representation theory.  Here are some highlights of results obtained under support from this grant:

- In joint work with W. Hardesty (and building on earlier joint work with W. Hardesty and S. Riche), the PI was able to prove the Humphreys conjecture, a 25-year-old problem regarding the homological properties of modular representations of Lie algebras.

- In joint work with S. Riche, the PI developed the foundations of a "geometric model" for modular Lie algebra representations.

- In ongoing joint work with J. Lourenço, T. Richarz, and S. Riche, the PI is working on developing a version of the geometric Satake equivalence for ramified groups.  This work would generalize and extend the usual (unramified) geometric Satake equivalence, a result due to I. Mirkovic and K. Vilonen (with contributions from many other mathematicians) that is a cornerstone of the geometric Langlands program, a web of ideas linking geometry, representation theory, and number theory. 

Finally, the most notable outcome of this project in terms of broader impacts is the publication of textbook (Perverse Sheaves and Applications to Representation Theory) aimed at advanced graduate students and early-career researchers.
